I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will develop policies and capacity, 
technical guidance, and design of pilots to combine and advance the concepts of zero waste cities 
and green circular economy cities in the People’s Republic of China (PRC).1 The TA will support 
the development of policies, institutional and technical solutions, business models, and private 
sector solutions to help the PRC become a leader in green circular economy zero waste cities, 
moving to full life-cycle concepts and internalization of external environmental and social costs. 
The  project’s  four  outputs  will  broadly  cover  (i)  advanced  upstream  circular  production;  
(ii) downstream improved waste management and resource recovery; (iii) midstream improved 
packaging  and  logistics,  addressing  growing  waste  from  e-commerce;  and  (iv)  building 
institutional capacity and linking the upstream, midstream, and downstream processes into a 
circular system of biological and technical cycles. Linking and integrating the comprehensive 
approach of green circular economy cities which requires systemic transformation and takes more 
time to fully implement, with the zero waste cities approach, that is a practice of resource recovery 
from waste aiming at near full reuse and recycling, will be a practical avenue to achieve more 
resource efficiency in a shorter period of time. 
 
2.  The TA is included in the list of projects agreed between the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) and the PRC Government on 22 January 2020. The TA is aligned with ADB’s country 
partnership strategy for the PRC, 2016–2020;2 and the following Operational Priorities of ADB’s 
Strategy 2030 (i) Priority 1: addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities; (ii) Priority 2: 
accelerating progress in gender equality; (iii) Priority 3: tackling climate change, building climate 
and disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability; and (iv) Priority 4: making 
cities more livable.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The increasing amount of natural resources demand and consumption in the current linear 
economic model of "take–make–waste," along with continued urban and economic growth and 
the  association  of  unsustainable  consumption  behavior  with  increased  well-being  are  key 
challenges to sustainable, low-carbon, and climate-resilient development in the PRC and around 
the world. In the current linear system, upstream production is inefficient and wasteful, midstream 
packaging and logistics management is inadequate and uses a lot of single-use plastics, and 
downstream solid waste management is still weak especially regarding product reuse and 
resource recovery rates. Existing production chains, consumption levels, and disposal practices 
inevitably lead to ecosystem depletion, waste, and environmental pollution. A holistic strategy of 
a green circular economy creating product life cycles that account for environmental, economic,

use are minimized. When a product reaches the end of its life, it is used again to create further value. This can bring 
major economic benefits, contributing to innovation, growth, and job creation. European Commission. 2015. Circular 
Economy Package: Questions & Answers. Memorandum. 2 December; and footnote 7, pp. 18–20.

optimize natural resource use efficiency, and eventually promote the idea that nothing should be 
considered “waste”.5 
 
4.  The PRC faces serious challenges related to high levels of resource use and rapidly 
increasing generation of solid waste, including packaging and logistics waste. Research from 
2016 suggests that the PRC requires 2.5 kilograms of materials to generate $1.0 of gross 
domestic product, compared with 0.5 kilograms in Organisation of Economic Co-operation and 
Development countries.6 The World Bank forecast in 2012 that urban solid waste generation in 
the PRC would reach 510.0 million metric tons per year by 2025 up from 190.0 million tons in 
2012.7 In 2018, the PRC decided to stop importing waste from other countries for processing. The 
rise of packaging waste from e-commerce has contributed to an overall increase in municipal solid 
waste in the PRC.8 This coincides with a growing urban population and economic growth 
associated with an increase in demand for products and resources, even as natural resources 
become more scarce. During the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, e-commerce and 
medical single-use plastics increased significantly compared with the same period in 2019.9 
 
5.  The TA will build on PRC efforts to conceptualize, pilot, and promote circular economy 
laws and regulations such as the Circular Economy Promotion Law of the PRC (2008) and the 
National Action Plan for Circular Economy Development adopted in 2017—including ambitious 
targets for resource recovery and circular industrial parks.10 The TA will also build on programs 
in the PRC to reduce, reuse, and recycle (the ”3R” principle) household waste and improve 
construction and demolition waste management. In addition, the TA will build on the National Zero 
Waste Cities pilot program under the Ministry of Ecology and Environment. There are many 
examples in the PRC of circular practices in agriculture and of water utilities reusing treated 
wastewater and wastewater treatment plants practicing effective sludge management.11 The TA 
will incorporate international best practices including the Circular Economy Action Plan of the 
European Union, who also engages in a formal cooperation with the PRC on the topic.12  
 
6.  The TA will build on lessons from previous and ongoing ADB loan and TA projects, 
including (i) Promoting Action on Plastic Pollution from Source to Sea in Asia and the Pacific;  
(ii) Study on Municipal Solid Waste Regional Integrated Management Model for Beijing–Tianjin–
Hebei; (iii) Construction and Demolition Waste Management and Recycling; (iv) Hunan Xiangjiang 
River Watershed Existing Solid Waste Comprehensive Treatment Project; (v) Agriculture Green

7.  The TA will conceptually and programmatically link into biological and technical cycles the 
three aspects of the current linear upstream, midstream, and downstream processes. Firstly, 
Qinghai Province will be a case targeting upstream heavy industrial production with raw material 
processing.  Secondly,  Guangdong  Province  will  be  a  case  targeting  downstream  waste 
management and resource recovery in highly developed urban centers with state of the art light 
industry manufacturing and services, and less-developed rural towns displaying differentiated 
levels and patterns of consumption and waste generation. Thirdly, pilot cities around the country 
of different sizes and development levels will be working together with relevant industry partners 
to address the midstream e-commerce packaging and logistics challenges, which represent a key 
link in the circular economy. Lastly, all three will be linked and lessons drawn for policies, technical 
guidance, and business models aiming at green circular economy zero waste cities. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  green  development  and  ecological 
civilization14 in the PRC achieved.15 The TA will have the following outcome: green circular 
economy zero waste cities in the PRC enabled.16  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Green circular industrial production plan of Qinghai Province advanced. 
This output will help Qinghai Province develop its circular economy by advancing a plan for green, 
low-carbon circular economy development in industrial parks, focusing on heavy industry and 
mining processing.17 Under this output, the TA team will research challenges, opportunities, and 
market failures and design advanced technical guidelines, policies, and pilots. Concepts to be 
considered  will  include  life  cycles  of  products  and  materials;  natural  resource  use;  linking 
industrial processes, energy efficiency, and renewable energy production and consumption; and 
missing upstream and downstream relationships. This output will include research on solutions to 
reduce pollutant emission and discharge; creation of new jobs, including jobs for the poor and for 
women; and local value addition. The output will also include components to raise awareness and 
promote behavioral change.

10.  Output 2: Zero municipal waste action plan for Guangdong Province developed. 
This output will focus on designing and prioritizing actions to significantly reducing household 
waste in Guangdong Province, with a goal of nearly full recovery of household waste. This output 
will  include  research  on  and  policy  design  for  household  waste  classification  and 
recommendations to efficiently manage segregation and recycling technologies in both highly 
developed urban centers and lesser developed towns and villages. The 3R principle will be 
applied in capacity development and in the action plan, and pilots will be designed to improve 
waste management and resource recovery. City governments, communities, households, and 
local businesses will be engaged through public awareness raising initiatives and government 
incentives will be proposed to encourage industry and people to do the "right things" (e.g., 
designing green products aimed at reducing or eliminating waste). The output will also propose 
options for government-imposed disincentives—such as charges, taxes, and levies—for doing 
the "wrong things" (e.g., continuing to produce waste and use up natural resources). 
 
11.  Output 3: Green circular e-commerce packaging and logistics pilot program for the 
People’s Republic of China developed. This output will focus on the important emerging 
challenge of reducing plastic pollution caused by significantly increasing e-commerce and food 
delivery, and associated packaging and logistics. It will support the development of a national pilot 
program customized for cities of various types, sizes, and development levels, engaging market 
players in e-commerce and logistics. It will explore new forms of recyclable and/or reusable 
packaging, logistics, and distribution equipment and facilities with the goal of creating a green 
supply chain in which single-use plastics are eliminated. Options for market-based instruments 
and business models will be explored and included in the design for the pilot program. 
 
12.  Output 4: Capacity and institutions to implement green circular economy in the 
People’s Republic of China enhanced. This output will develop the capacity of and provide 
policy and technical guidance for cities, institutions, and companies to promote and implement 
green circular economy zero waste cities. The TA expert team will link into biological and technical 
cycles improved upstream, midstream, and downstream processes, integrating the findings and 
recommendations from outputs 1, 2, and 3, offering policy recommendations and technical and 
business model options. It will include components to raise public awareness on resource scarcity 
and environmental challenges of solid waste, and raise the sense of producer and consumer 
responsibility promoting a circular economy and the need for reducing waste. Cases with lessons 
from previous projects in the PRC and other countries will be prepared and incorporated. 
Collaboration with the ADB TA project Promoting Action on Plastic Pollution from Source to Sea 
in Asia and the Pacific (footnote 13) is planned through mutual participation in training events.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $735,000, of which $667,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
14.  The Qinghai Provincial Government, Guangdong Provincial Government, and National 
Development  and  Reform  Commission  (NDRC)  Circular  Economy  Division  will  provide 
counterpart staff, office accommodation, meeting venues, miscellaneous administration expenses, 
and other in-kind contributions. Additional funding sources are being pursued to enhance capacity 
building and design of pilots.

5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TA. The Urban and Social Sectors Division of the East Asia 
Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants and monitor the quality of their work. 
The  executing  agencies  will  be  (i)  Qinghai  Provincial  Finance  Department  for  output  1,  
(ii) Guangdong Provincial Finance Department for output 2, and (iii) NDRC for outputs 3 and 4. 
The implementing agencies will be (i) Qinghai Provincial Development and Reform Commission 
for output 1, (ii) Guangdong Provincial Housing and Urban–Rural Development Department for 
output 2, and (iii) NDRC Circular Economy Division for output 3. The three implementing agencies 
will jointly implement output 4 and they will provide day-to-day supervision of TA implementation 
and guide and support to the consultants engaged under the TA.
